title: Managing Metastatic Breast Cancer and Bipolar Disorder

content: Living with metastatic breast cancer can be challenging enough, but what happens when you also have a mental health condition such as bipolar disorder? I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder in October 2000, nearly 18 years before my metastatic breast cancer (MBC) diagnosis.

My journey with bipolar disorder has been difficult, and when MBC entered the picture, I knew I would have to figure out how to manage the challenges that come with both illnesses. It’s not impossible, but time has shown me that it is a delicate balancing act. I’m often afraid of losing my footing, so I’ve learned some tips along the way to help keep me grounded.

Metastatic breast cancer, also known as stage IV breast cancer, is a form of cancer that has spread beyond the breast to other parts of the body, such as the bones, liver, or lungs. Treatment options for metastatic breast cancer include chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and hormone therapy. Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition that causes extreme shifts in mood, energy, and activity levels. People with bipolar disorder may experience periods of elevated or irritable moods, known as manic or hypomanic episodes, as well as periods of depression. Both illnesses require a treatment plan, under the guidance of medical professionals, to provide the best possible outcome and include medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes.

content: I struggled with managing symptoms of bipolar disorder for many years. During severe periods of depression alternating with mania, I struggled to keep jobs, stay in school, and have meaningful relationships. I felt ashamed about my diagnosis due to the stigma that surrounds mental illness. I spent time in inpatient and outpatient programs during severe crises. It took a lot of time, effort, and discipline on my part to find the right combination of medications and therapy to help manage the often-overwhelming symptoms.

When I was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer, I was in a manic episode. The bipolar high helped in an unlikely way. I was convinced I could beat my incurable stage IV diagnosis and that energy remained with me all through chemotherapy and the beginning of active treatment. The outside world saw me as exceptionally positive, but really I was just manic. They didn’t see the fear that was underneath the surface. People were much more supportive of my breast cancer diagnosis than they had ever been of my bipolar disorder.

content: I was entering a depressive episode when I received my first set of clear scans. I would now be managing these two illnesses for the rest of my life. The shocking realization that I would need cancer treatments indefinitely worsened my bipolar symptoms. My thoughts got really dark. I had spent a huge chunk of my life not wanting to live and now because of cancer, I was also fighting to live.

Each condition can impact the other. Some of the side effects of the cancer treatments like nausea and fatigue, as well as the uncertainty that comes with living with MBC, exacerbated the bipolar symptoms. It was too much.  I knew that I would need to find ways to cope with both.
Here are some ways to manage both conditions simultaneously:
bullets: Work closely with your health care team . It is important that your health care teams are on the same page with helping you. Make sure that the oncology team, primary care doctor, therapist, and psychiatrist are aware of all your medications and treatments to ensure there are no interactions.

Seek support. Join a support group or reach out to friends and family for emotional support. I had already been in therapy for several years prior to my MBC diagnosis and continued going to it. I joined a weekly DBT group to learn new ways of coping that have helped with the feelings that arise from both MBC and bipolar disorder. I eventually sought out support in the breast cancer community as well. I wish I hadn’t waited so long to reach out to others.

Prioritize self-care . Taking care of your physical and mental health is vital. Eating a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and engaging in stress-reducing activities is a huge help for both conditions.

Advocate for yourself. Don’t be afraid to speak up about your needs and preferences with treatment. Sometimes I need to get my bipolar medications adjusted when I’m symptomatic or dealing with side effects from the cancer treatments. I know my body best, so I want to make sure my health providers have my best interests in mind.

content: Living with metastatic breast cancer and bipolar disorder can be a challenging journey, but it’s important to remember that it isn’t impossible to manage both conditions simultaneously. Try to take it one day at a time and remain mindful of the way your body and mind feel.

You can manage both conditions and improve your quality of life by working closely with your health care team, seeking support, prioritizing self-care, and advocating for yourself. Remember, you’re not alone in this journey. There are resources and support available to help you along the way.
